== Tunneling current and force measurement principle == The tip itself does not have any working principle for imaging, but depending on the instrumentation, mode of application, and the nature of the sample under investigation, the probe tip may follow different principle to image the surface of the sample. For example, when a tip is integrated with STM, it measures the tunneling current that arises from the interaction between the sample and the tip.<ref name="Binnig et al 1982" /><ref name="Tersoff & Hamann 1983"/> In AFM, short-ranged force deflection during the raster scan by tip across the surface is measured.<ref name=pmid10033323/> A conductive tip is essential for the STM instrumentation whereas AFM can use conductive<ref name=pmid18654521/><ref name=":27">{{cite journal |doi=10.1063/1.117179 |title=Imaging the local electrical properties of metal surfaces by atomic force microscopy with conducting probes |journal=Applied Physics Letters |volume=69 |issue=13 |pages=1975–1977 |year=1996 |last1=Houzé |first1=F |last2=Meyer |first2=R |last3=Schneegans |first3=O |last4=Boyer |first4=L }}</ref> and non-conductive<ref name=":28">{{Cite journal |last=Kaiser |first=Uwe |last2=Schwarz |first2=Alexander |last3=Wiesendanger |first3=Roland |date=2007-03 |title=Magnetic exchange force microscopy with atomic resolution |journal=Nature |volume=446 |issue=7135 |pages=522–5 |doi=10.1038/nature05617 |pmid=17392782 }}</ref> prob tip. Although probe tip is used in various techniques with different principle, for STM and AFM coupled with probe tip is discussed in detail.<ref name="Dai et al 1996"/><ref name=":12">{{Cite journal |last=Gray |first=Robert C. |last2=Fishman |first2=Victor A. |last3=Bard |first3=Allen J. |date=May 1977 |title=Simple sample cell for examination of solids and liquids by photoacoustic spectroscopy |journal=Analytical Chemistry |volume=49 |issue=6 |pages=697–700 |doi=10.1021/ac50014a009 }}</ref><ref name=pmid19829577>{{cite journal |doi=10.1364/OL.19.000159 |pmid=19829577 |title=Near-field scanning optical microscope with a metallic probe tip |journal=Optics Letters |volume=19 |issue=3 |pages=159 |year=1994 |last1=Inouye |first1=Yasushi |last2=Kawata |first2=Satoshi }}</ref><ref name=":30">{{cite journal |pmid=11884326 |pmc=1122512 |year=2002 |last1=Müller |first1=M |title=Science, medicine, and the future: Microdialysis |journal=BMJ |volume=324 |issue=7337 |pages=588–91 }}</ref><ref name=pmid17811409>{{Cite journal |last=Frisbie |first=C. Daniel |last2=Rozsnyai |first2=Lawrence F. |last3=Noy |first3=Aleksandr |last4=Wrighton |first4=Mark S. |last5=Lieber |first5=Charles M. |date=1994-09-30 |title=Functional Group Imaging by Chemical Force Microscopy |journal=Science |volume=265 |issue=5181 |pages=2071–4 |doi=10.1126/science.265.5181.2071 |pmid=17811409 }}</ref>
=== Conductive probe tip === Somewhat, the name implies STM utilizes tunneling charge transfer principle from tip to surface or vice versa thereby recording the current response. This concept originates from particle in a box concept, that is, if potential energy for a particle is small, electron may be found outside of potential well which is a classically forbidden region. This phenomenon is called tunneling.<ref name=":32">{{Cite book|doi=10.1093/acprof:oso/9780199589494.003.0001 |chapter=Introduction |title=Principles of Electron Tunneling Spectroscopy ''Second'' Edition |pages=1–22 |year=2011 |last1=Wolf |first1=E. L |isbn=9780199589494 }}</ref>
Expression derived from Schrodinger equation for transmission charge transfer probability is as follow:
<math>T=16\epsilon(1-\epsilon)^{-2k}</math>
where : <math>\epsilon = \frac{E}{V} = \text{Kinetic energy/potential energy}</math> : <math>k = 2\pi \sqrt{\frac{2mE}{h}}</math> : <math>h</math> is the [[Planck constant]]
=== Non-conductive probe tip === Non-conductive nano-scale tips are widely used for AFM measurements. For non-conducting tip, surface forces acting on the tip/cantilever, are responsible for deflection or attraction of tip.<ref name=":34">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0014-5793(96)00651-5 |title=In situ observation of streptavidin-biotin binding on an immunoassay well surface using an atomic force microscope |journal=FEBS Letters |volume=390 |issue=2 |pages=161–164 |year=1996 |last1=Allen |first1=S |last2=Davies |first2=J |last3=Dawkes |first3=A.C |last4=Davies |first4=M.C |last5=Edwards |first5=J.C |last6=Parker |first6=M.C |last7=Roberts |first7=C.J |last8=Sefton |first8=J |last9=Tendler |first9=S.J.B |last10=Williams |first10=P.M }}</ref> These attractive or repulsive forces are used for surface topology, chemical specifications, magnetic and electronic properties. The distance dependent forces between substrate surface and tip are responsible for imaging in AFM.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Barattin |first=Régis |last2=Voyer |first2=Normand |date=2008 |title=Chemical modifications of AFM tips for the study of molecular recognition events |journal=Chemical Communications |volume=0 |issue=13 |page=1513 |doi=10.1039/B614328H }}</ref> These interactions include are van der Waals forces, capillary forces, electrostatic forces, Casimir forces and solvation forces. One unique repulsion force is Pauli Exclusion repulsive force<ref name=pmid19713523>{{Cite journal |last=Gross |first=Leo |last2=Mohn |first2=Fabian |last3=Moll |first3=Nikolaj |last4=Liljeroth |first4=Peter |last5=Meyer |first5=Gerhard |date=2009-08-28 |title=The Chemical Structure of a Molecule Resolved by Atomic Force Microscopy |journal=Science |volume=325 |issue=5944 |pages=1110–4 |doi=10.1126/science.1176210 |pmid=19713523}}</ref> is responsible for single atom imaging as in references<ref name=pmid19713523/><ref name=pmid22984067>{{Cite journal |last=Gross |first=Leo |last2=Mohn |first2=Fabian |last3=Moll |first3=Nikolaj |last4=Schuler |first4=Bruno |last5=Criado |first5=Alejandro |last6=Guitián |first6=Enrique |last7=Peña |first7=Diego |last8=Gourdon |first8=André |last9=Meyer |first9=Gerhard |date=2012-09-14 |title=Bond-Order Discrimination by Atomic Force Microscopy |journal=Science |volume=337 |issue=6100 |pages=1326–9 |doi=10.1126/science.1225621 |pmid=22984067 }}</ref><ref name=pmid17811409/> and Figures 10 & 11 (contact region in Fig. 1). [[File:Force measurement with tip.png|thumb|Fig. 1: Typical forces dependence on probe substrate distance.]]
== Fabrication methods == Tip fabrication techniques fall generally in any two classifications: mechanical and physicochemical. In the early stage of development of probe tips, mechanical procedures were popular because of ease of fabrication. One of mechanical method for the fabrication of hydrogel tip will be discussed in detail.
=== Mechanical methods === A few reported mechanical methods to fabricate tips include cutting<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1063/1.1143892 |title=The use of silver tips in scanning tunneling microscopy |journal=Review of Scientific Instruments |volume=64 |issue=8 |pages=2393–2394 |year=1993 |last1=Gorbunov |first1=A. A |last2=Wolf |first2=B |last3=Edelmann |first3=J }}</ref><ref name=":14">{{cite journal |doi=10.1116/1.576417 |title=Transmission electron microscopy of scanning tunneling tips |journal=Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology A: Vacuum, Surfaces, and Films |volume=8 |pages=441–444 |year=1990 |last1=Garnaes |first1=J |last2=Kragh |first2=F |last3=Mo/Rch |first3=K. A |last4=Thölén |first4=A. R }}</ref> grinding<ref name=":15">{{Cite journal |last=Mate |first=C. Mathew |last2=McClelland |first2=Gary M. |last3=Erlandsson |first3=Ragnar |last4=Chiang |first4=Shirley |date=1987-10-26 |title=Atomic-scale friction of a tungsten tip on a graphite surface |journal=Physical Review Letters |volume=59 |issue=17 |pages=1942–1945 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.59.1942|pmid=10035374 }}</ref><ref name=":16">{{Cite journal |last=Liu |first=Hsue Yang. |last2=Fan |first2=Fu Ren F. |last3=Lin |first3=Charles W. |last4=Bard |first4=Allen J. |date=June 1986 |title=Scanning electrochemical and tunneling ultramicroelectrode microscope for high-resolution examination of electrode surfaces in solution |journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society |volume=108 |issue=13 |pages=3838–3839 |doi=10.1021/ja00273a054 }}</ref> and pulling.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1063/1.1589584 |title=Formation of fine near-field scanning optical microscopy tips. Part II. By laser-heated pulling and bending |journal=Review of Scientific Instruments |volume=74 |issue=8 |pages=3684–3688 |year=2003 |last1=Lazarev |first1=Alexander |last2=Fang |first2=Nicholas |last3=Luo |first3=Qi |last4=Zhang |first4=Xiang }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Essaidi |first=N. |last2=Chen |first2=Y. |last3=Kottler |first3=V. |last4=Cambril |first4=E. |last5=Mayeux |first5=C. |last6=Ronarch |first6=N. |last7=Vieu |first7=C. |date=1998-02-01 |title=Fabrication and characterization of optical-fiber nanoprobes for scanning near-field optical microscopy |journal=Applied Optics |volume=37 |issue=4 |pages=609–615 |doi=10.1364/AO.37.000609 }}</ref> For example, cutting a wire at certain angles with razor blade or wire cutter or scissor.<ref name=":14" /> Another mechanical method for tip preparation is fragmentation of bulk pieces into small pointy pieces. Grinding a metal wire/rod into a sharp tip was also a method used.<ref name=":15" /><ref name=":16" /> These mechanical procedures usually leave rugged surface with many tiny asperities protruding from the apex which lead to atomic resolution on flat surface. However, irregular shape and large macroscopic radius of curvature result in poor reproducibility and decreased stability especially for probing rough surfaces. Another main disadvantage of making probe by this method is it yields many mini tips which lead to many different signals yielding error in imaging.<ref name=":17">{{Cite thesis |last=Gobind |first=Basnet, |title=Fabrication of Tungsten Tips Suitable for Scanning Probe Microscopy by Electrochemical Etching Methods |date=2013 |publisher=University of Arkansas, Fayetteville |url=http://scholarworks.uark.edu/etd/865/ }}</ref> Cutting, grinding and pulling procedures can only be adapted for metallic tips like W, Ag, Pt, Ir, Pt-Ir and gold. Non-metallic tips cannot be fabricated by these methods.
On other hand a sophisticated mechanical method for tip fabrication is based on hydro-gel method.<ref name=":11" /> This method is based on bottom-up strategy to make probe tips by molecular self-assembly process. First, cantilever is formed in mold by curing pre-polymer solution then it is brought into contact with mold of tip which contains pre-polymer solution. The polymer is cured with ultraviolet light which helps firmly attachment of cantilever with probe. This fabrication method is shown in Fig. 2.<ref name=":11" />
=== Physio-chemical procedures === Physiochemical procedures are fabrication methods of choice these days which yield extremely sharp and symmetric tips with more reproducibility compared to mechanical fabrication-based tips. Among physicochemical method, the electrochemical etching method<ref name=":7" /> is one of the most popular method. Etching is two or more steps procedure. The “zone electropolishing” is the second step which further sharpens the tip in a very controlled manner. Other physicochemical methods include chemical vapor deposition,<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Cheung |first=Chin Li |last2=Hafner |first2=Jason H. |last3=Lieber |first3=Charles M. |date=2000-04-11 |title=Carbon nanotube atomic force microscopy tips: Direct growth by chemical vapor deposition and application to high-resolution imaging |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences |volume=97 |issue=8 |pages=3809–13 |doi=10.1073/pnas.050498597 |pmid=10737761|pmc=18098 }}</ref> electron beam deposition onto pre-existing tips.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Martinez |first=J. |last2=Yuzvinsky |first2=T. D. |last3=Fennimore |first3=A. M. |last4=Zettl |first4=A. |last5=García |first5=R. |last6=Bustamante |first6=C. |date=2005 |title=Length control and sharpening of atomic force microscope carbon nanotube tips assisted by an electron beam |journal=Nanotechnology |volume=16 |issue=11 |page=2493 |doi=10.1088/0957-4484/16/11/004 |url=https://digital.csic.es/bitstream/10261/50510/1/accesoRestringido.pdf |format=Submitted manuscript }}</ref> Other tip fabrication methods include field ion microscopy<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Lucier |first=Anne-Sophie |last2=Mortensen |first2=Henrik |last3=Sun |first3=Yan |last4=Grütter |first4=Peter |date=2005-12-19 |title=Determination of the atomic structure of scanning probe microscopy tungsten tips by field ion microscopy |journal=Physical Review B |volume=72 |issue=23 |page=235420 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.72.235420 }}</ref> and ion milling.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1063/1.1842352 |title=Nanodispenser for attoliter volume deposition using atomic force microscopy probes modified by focused-ion-beam milling |journal=Applied Physics Letters |volume=85 |issue=25 |pages=6260–6262 |year=2004 |last1=Meister |first1=A |last2=Liley |first2=M |last3=Brugger |first3=J |last4=Pugin |first4=R |last5=Heinzelmann |first5=H |url=https://infoscience.epfl.ch/record/58432/files/Meister_2004_APL.pdf |format=Full text }}</ref> In field ion microscopy techniques, consecutive field evaporation of single atoms yields specific atomic configuration at probe tip which yields very high resolution.<ref name=":17" />
==== Fabrication through etching ==== Electrochemical etching is one of the easiest, inexpensive, most practical, reliable and most widely accepted metallic probe tip fabrication method with desired quality and reproducibility.<ref name=":8" /> Three commonly used electrochemical etching for tungsten tip fabrication are: single lamella drop-off methods,<ref name=":17" /> double lamella drop-off method<ref name=":10" /> and submerged method.<ref name=":18">{{cite journal |doi=10.1116/1.589029 |title=Preparation of sharp polycrystalline tungsten tips for scanning tunneling microscopy imaging |journal=Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology B: Microelectronics and Nanometer Structures |volume=14 |pages=1 |year=1996 |last1=Zhang |first1=R }}</ref> Various cone shape tips can be fabricated by this method by minor changes in the experimental setup. An DC potential between tip and metallic electrode (usually W wire) immersed in solution (Figure 3 a-c). Electrochemical reactions at cathode and anode in basic solutions (2M KOH or 2M NaOH) are usually used.<ref name=":6" /> The overall etching process involved is written here:
Anode;
<chem>W (s) + 8OH- -> WO4 + 4H2O + 6e- (E= 1.05V)</chem>
Cathode:
<chem>6H2O + 6e- -> 3H2 + 6OH- (E=-2.48V)</chem>
Overall:
<chem>W (s) + 2OH- -> WO4^2- + 2H2O (l) + 6e- + 3H2 (g) (E= -1.43V)</chem>
Here, all the potentials are reported vs. SHE.
[[File:Etching drop.png|thumb|Fig. 3: Schematics of fabrication method of probe tip through electrochemical etching method.]]
Schematics of fabrication method of probe tip through electrochemical etching method is shown in Fig. 3.
Experimental setup for Electrochemical etching is shown in Fig. 3a.<ref name=":19">{{Cite journal |last=Lee |first=Chanwoo |last2=Kim |first2=Sung Tae |last3=Jeong |first3=Byeong Geun |last4=Yun |first4=Seok Joon |last5=Song |first5=Young Jae |last6=Lee |first6=Young Hee |last7=Park |first7=Doo Jae |last8=Jeong |first8=Mun Seok |date=2017-01-13 |title=Tip-Enhanced Raman Scattering Imaging of Two-Dimensional Tungsten Disulfide with Optimized Tip Fabrication Process |journal=Scientific Reports |volume=7 |page=40810 |doi=10.1038/srep40810 }}</ref>
Different tips fabricated from etching method with different tip radius and angle is illustrated in Fig. 3(b-e).<ref name=":19" />
In electrochemical etching process, W is etched at liquid, solid and air interface (due to surface tension), as shown in Fig. 3. Etching is called static if W wire is kept stationary. Once the tip is etched, lower part falls due to the lower tensile strength than the weight of lower part of wire. The irregular shape is produced by the shifting of meniscus. However, slow etching rate can produce regular tips which controlling current slowly through electrochemical cell. The dynamic etching involves slowly pulling up the wire from solution or sometimes it is moved up and down (oscillating wire) producing smooth tips.<ref name=":9" />
==== Submerged method ==== In this method a metal wire is vertically etched reducing the diameter from 0.25 mm ~ 20 nm. Schematic diagram for probe tip fabrication with submerged electrochemical etching method is illustrated in Fig 4. These tips can be used for high quality STM images.<ref name=":17" /> [[File:Submerged Method.png|thumb|Fig. 4: Schematic diagram for probe tip fabrication with submerged electrochemical etching method (W wire)]]
==== Lamella method ==== In double lamella method the lower part of metal is etched away, and upper part of tip was not etched further.<ref name=":10" /> Further etching of the upper part of wire is prevented by covering it with a polymer coating. This method is usually limited to laboratory fabrication.<ref name=":17" /> Double lamella method schematic is shown in Fig. 5. [[File:Double-Lamella.png|thumb|Fig. 5: A typical double-lamella drop-off electrochemical etching set up]]
=== Single atom tip preparation === Transitions metals like Cu, Au and Ag adsorbs single molecules linearly on their surface due to weak van der Waals forces.<ref name=pmid19713523/> This linear projection of single molecule allows interaction of terminal atom of tip with atom of substrate resulting in Pauli repulsion for single molecule or atom mapping studies. Gases deposition on tip is carried out in an ultrahigh vacuum (5 x 10<sup>−8</sup> mbar) chamber at a low temperature (10K). Deposition of Xe, Kr, NO, CH<sub>4</sub> or CO <ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1063/1.4934273 |title=CO tip functionalization in subatomic resolution atomic force microscopy |journal=Applied Physics Letters |volume=107 |issue=16 |pages=163109 |year=2015 |last1=Kim |first1=Minjung |last2=Chelikowsky |first2=James R }}</ref> on tip have been successfully prepared and used for imaging studies. However, these tips preparation rely on attachment of single atom or molecule on tip and resulting atomic structure of tip is not known exactly.<ref name=pmid22984067/><ref name=":37">{{Cite journal |last=Zhang |first=Jun |last2=Chen |first2=Pengcheng |last3=Yuan |first3=Bingkai |last4=Ji |first4=Wei |last5=Cheng |first5=Zhihai |last6=Qiu |first6=Xiaohui |date=2013-11-01 |title=Real-Space Identification of Intermolecular Bonding with Atomic Force Microscopy |journal=Science |volume=342 |issue=6158 |pages=611–614 |doi=10.1126/science.1242603 |pmid=24072819}}</ref> Probability of attachment of simple molecule on metals surface is very tedious and required great skills. Therefore, this method is not ubiquitous and not many laws are able to perform these experiments.
=== Chemical vapor deposition (CVD) === Sharp tips used in SPM are fragile and prone to damage and wear and tear easily under high working load. Diamond is considered the best option to address this issue.<ref name=":20">{{cite journal |doi=10.1063/1.118173 |title=Fabrication of small diamond tips for scanning probe microscopy application |journal=Applied Physics Letters |volume=70 |issue=4 |pages=435–437 |year=1997 |last1=Oesterschulze |first1=E |last2=Scholz |first2=W |last3=Mihalcea |first3=Ch |last4=Albert |first4=D |last5=Sobisch |first5=B |last6=Kulisch |first6=W }}</ref> Diamond tips for SPM application are fabricated by fracture of bulk diamond, grinding and polishing diamond.<ref name=":20" /> But, these methods result in considerable loss of diamond. Other strategy to prevent this loss is coating of Silicone tips with thin diamond film.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1063/1.1143265 |title=Diamond force microscope tips fabricated by chemical vapor deposition |journal=Review of Scientific Instruments |volume=63 |issue=9 |pages=4053–4055 |year=1992 |last1=Germann |first1=G. J |last2=McClelland |first2=G. M |last3=Mitsuda |first3=Y |last4=Buck |first4=M |last5=Seki |first5=H }}</ref> These thin films are usually deposited by CVD.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/pssa.2211540113 |title=On the Mechanisms of Bias Enhanced Nucleation of Diamond |journal=Physica Status Solidi A |volume=154 |pages=155–174 |year=1996 |last1=Kulisch |first1=W |last2=Ackermann |first2=L |last3=Sobisch |first3=B }}</ref> In CVD, diamond is deposited directly on silicon or W cantilever. A schematic diagram for chemical vapor deposition set up is shown in Fig. 6. In this method, flow of methane and hydrogen gas is maintained in such a way that pressure inside chamber is maintained at 40Torr. CH<sub>4</sub> and H<sub>2</sub> are dissociated at elevated temperature of 2100 °C with the help of Ta filament. Nucleation sites are created on the tip of cantilever. Once CVD is complete, CH<sub>4</sub> flow is stopped and chamber is cooled under flow of H<sub>2</sub>. Schematics of CVD set up for diamond tip fabrication for AFM application is in Fig. 6.
[[File:Chemical Vapor Deposition.png|thumb|Fig. 6: Schematics of CVD set up for diamond tip fabrication for AFM application]]
=== Reactive ion etching (RIE) fabrication === In RIE method, first a grove or structure is made on a substrate followed by deposition of a desired material in that template. Once tip is formed, templating structure is etched off leaving tip and cantilever. A schematic for diamond tip fabrication on silicon wafers through this method has been described in Fig. 7<ref name=":39">{{Cite journal |last=Calafiore |first=Giuseppe |last2=Koshelev |first2=Alexander |last3=Darlington |first3=Thomas P. |last4=Borys |first4=Nicholas J. |last5=Melli |first5=Mauro |last6=Polyakov |first6=Aleksandr |last7=Cantarella |first7=Giuseppe |last8=Allen |first8=Frances I. |last9=Lum |first9=Paul |date=2017-05-10 |title=Campanile Near-Field Probes Fabricated by Nanoimprint Lithography on the Facet of an Optical Fiber |journal=Scientific Reports |volume=7 |issue=1 |doi=10.1038/s41598-017-01871-5 }}</ref>
=== Focused ion beam milling === Focused ion beam milling milling is a sharpening method for probe tips in SPM. In this method, first a blunt tip is fabricated by other methods, for example, pyramid mold can be used to fabricate pyramidal tip, CVD method or any other etching method. Then, this tip is sharpened by FIB milling as shown in Fig. 8. The focused ion beam diameter is controlled through a programmable aperture which directly correlates with tip diameter.<ref name=":12" /> [[File:Fig. 8 Schematics of FIB milling method for probe tip sharpening.png|thumb|Fig 8: Schematics of focused ion beam milling milling method for probe tip sharpening]]
=== Glue === This method is used to attach carbon nanotubes on cantilever or blunt tip. A strong adhesive (such as soft acrylic glue) is used to bind CNT with silicon cantilever. CNT are robust, stiff and increase durability of probe tip and can be used for both contact and tapping mode.<ref name="Dai et al 1996"/><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Nguyen |first=Cattien V. |last2=Ye |first2=Qi |last3=Meyyappan |first3=M. |date=2005 |title=Carbon nanotube tips for scanning probe microscopy: fabrication and high aspect ratio nanometrology |journal=Measurement Science and Technology |volume=16 |issue=11 |page=2138 |doi=10.1088/0957-0233/16/11/003 }}</ref>
== Cleaning procedures == Electrochemically etched tips are usually covered with contaminant on surface which cannot be removed simply by rinsing in water, acetone or ethanol. Some oxides layers on metallic tips, especially on tungsten, need to be removed by post fabrication treatment.
=== Annealing === To clean W sharp tips, it is highly desirable to remove contaminant and oxide layer. In this method a tip is heated in UHV chamber at elevated temperature which desorb contaminated layer. Reaction detail is shown below.<ref name=":21">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0039-6028(92)91036-B |title=Preparation of STM W tips and characterization by FEM, TEM and SEM |journal=Surface Science |volume=266 |pages=294–298 |year=1992 |last1=Méndez |first1=J |last2=Luna |first2=M |last3=Baró |first3=A.M }}</ref>
2WO<sub>3</sub> + W → 3WO<sub>2</sub> ↑
WO<sub>2</sub> → W (sublimation at <math>\backsim</math>1075K)
As at elevated temperature, trioxides of W are converted to WO<sub>2</sub> which sublimates around 1075K and cleaned metallic W surface left behind. Additional advantage provided by annealing is healing of crystallographic defects produced by fabrication and it also smoothens the tip surface.
=== HF chemical cleaning === In HF cleaning method, freshly prepared tip is dipped in 15% concentrated hydrofluoric acid which dissolves oxides of W for 10~30 s.<ref>{{Citation |title=Method of cleaning probe tips of cards and apparatus for implementing the method |date=1996-04-03 |url=https://patents.google.com/patent/US5814158A/en |accessdate=2018-05-15}}</ref>
=== Ion milling === In this method, argon ions are directed to the tip surface to remove contaminant layer by sputtering. Tip is either rotated in a flux of argon ions at certain angle in a way that this beam hits on the apex. The bombardment of ions on the tip depletes the contaminants and also results in reduction of radius of tip.<ref name=":12" /> Bombardment time needs to be finely tuned with respect to shape of tip. Sometimes, a short annealing is required after ion milling.<ref name=":21" />
=== Self-sputtering === This method is very similar to ion milling but, in this procedure, UHV chamber is filled with neon at a pressure of 10<sup>−4</sup> mbar. When negative voltage is applied on the tip, strong electric field (produced by tip under negative potential) will ionize neon gas and these positively charged ions are accelerated back to tip and causing sputtering at the tip. The sputtering removes contaminants and some atoms from tip which, like ion milling reduces apex radius. By, changing the field strength, one can tune radius of tip to 20 nm.<ref name=":21" />
== Coating == The surface of the Silicon based tips cannot be easily controlled because they usually carry silanol group. Si surface is hydrophilic and can be contaminated easily by environmental. Another disadvantage of Si tips is wear and tear of tip. It is important to coat Si tip to prevent tip deteriorations. The tip coating may also enhance image quality. Following types of coatings are employed for Si tips. First an adhesive layer is pasted (usually chromium layer on 5 nm thick titanium) and then gold is deposited by vapor deposition (40-100 nm or less). Sometimes, the coating layering reduces tunneling current detection capability of probe tips.<ref name=":21" /><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.apsusc.2006.07.070 |title=C-AFM-based thickness determination of thin and ultra-thin SiO 2 films by use of different conductive-coated probe tips |journal=Applied Surface Science |volume=253 |issue=7 |pages=3615–3626 |year=2007 |last1=Frammelsberger |first1=Werner |last2=Benstetter |first2=Guenther |last3=Kiely |first3=Janice |last4=Stamp |first4=Richard }}</ref>
== Characterization == The most important aspect of a probe tip is imaging the surfaces efficiently at nanometer. Some concerns involving credibility of the imaging or measurement of sample arises when the shape of tip is not determined accurately. For example, when an unknown tip is used to measure linewidth pattern or other high aspect ratio feature of a surface. There may remain some confusion for the determination of the contribution of tip and the sample in the acquired image.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1063/1.1651638 |title=Metrological large range scanning probe microscope |journal=Review of Scientific Instruments |volume=75 |issue=4 |pages=962–969 |year=2004 |last1=Dai |first1=Gaoliang |last2=Pohlenz |first2=Frank |last3=Danzebrink |first3=Hans-Ulrich |last4=Xu |first4=Min |last5=Hasche |first5=Klaus |last6=Wilkening |first6=Guenter }}</ref> Consequently, it is important to fully and accurately characterize the tips. Probe tips can be characterized for their shape, size, sharpness, bluntness, aspect ratio, radius of curvature, geometry and composition using many advanced instrumental techniques.<ref name=":11" /><ref name=":14" /><ref name=":18" /><ref name=":22">{{Cite journal |date=1992-07-01 |title=Field emission current-voltage curves as a diagnostic for scanning tunneling microscope tips |journal=Ultramicroscopy |volume=42-44 |pages=1538–1541 |doi=10.1016/0304-3991(92)90479-4 |last1=Meyer |first1=J.A |last2=Stranick |first2=S.J |last3=Wang |first3=J.B |last4=Weiss |first4=P.S |url=http://www.dtic.mil/cgi-bin/GetTRDoc?AD=ADA251171&Location=U2&doc=GetTRDoc.pdf |format=Submitted manuscript }}</ref><ref name=":23">{{cite journal |doi=10.1063/1.98070 |title=Ion milled tips for scanning tunneling microscopy |journal=Applied Physics Letters |volume=50 |issue=11 |pages=696–698 |year=1987 |last1=Biegelsen |first1=D. K |last2=Ponce |first2=F. A |last3=Tramontana |first3=J. C |last4=Koch |first4=S. M }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/BF00321548 |title=Characterization of tungsten tips for STM by SEM/AES/XPS |journal=Fresenius' Journal of Analytical Chemistry |volume=341 |issue=3–4 |pages=196–199 |year=1991 |last1=Lisowski |first1=W |last2=Van Den Berg |first2=A. H. J |last3=Kip |first3=G. A. M |last4=Hanekamp |first4=L. J |url=https://ris.utwente.nl/ws/files/6508706/art_10.1007_BF00321548.pdf |format=Submitted manuscript }}</ref> For example, electron field emission measurement, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning tunneling spectroscopy as well as more easily accessible optical microscope. In some cases, optical microscopy cannot provide exact measurements for small tips in nanoscale due to resolution limitation of the optical microscopy.
=== Electron field emission current measurement === In electron field emission current measurement method, a high voltage is applied between tip and another electrode followed by measuring field emission current employing Fowler-Nordheim curves <math>[\log_{10}(1/V^2) vs. (1/V)] </math>.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1126/science.270.5239.1179 |title=A Carbon Nanotube Field-Emission Electron Source |journal=Science |volume=270 |issue=5239 |pages=1179–1180 |year=1995 |last1=De Heer |first1=W. A |last2=Ch Telain |first2=A |last3=Ugarte |first3=D }}</ref> Large fields-emission current measurements may indicate that the tip is sharp and low field-emission current indicates that the tip is blunt, molten or mechanically damaged. A minimum voltage is essential to facilitate the release of electrons from the surface of tip which in turn indirectly is used to obtain the tip curvature. The downside of this method to the several advantages is that the high electric field required for producing strong electric force that can melt the apex of the tip or might change crystallographic tip nature.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":22" />
=== Scanning electron microscopy and transmission electron microscopy === The size and shape of the tip can be obtained by scanning electron microscopy and transmission electron microscopy measurements.<ref name=":18" /><ref name=":24">{{cite journal |doi=10.1063/1.1143970 |title=Calibration of atomic‐force microscope tips |journal=Review of Scientific Instruments |volume=64 |issue=7 |pages=1868–1873 |year=1993 |last1=Hutter |first1=Jeffrey L |last2=Bechhoefer |first2=John }}</ref> In addition, TEM images are helpful to detect any layer of insulating materials on the surface of the tip as well as to estimate the size of the layer. These oxides are formed gradually on the surface of tip the right after fabrication due to the oxidation of metallic tip by reacting with the O<sub>2</sub> present in the surrounding atmosphere.<ref name=":23" /> SEM has a resolution limitation of below 4 nm, TEM may be needed to observe even a single atom theoretically and practically. Tip grain down to 1-3 nm or thin polycrystalline oxides or carbon or graphite layers at the tip apex are routinely measured using TEM. The orientation of tip crystal i.e. the angle between the tip plane in the single-crystal and the tip normal can be estimated.<ref name=":14" /><ref name=":18" /><ref name=":23" /><ref name=":24" /><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1088/0950-7671/44/12/428 |title=Preparation of contamination-free tungsten specimens for the field-ion microscope |journal=Journal of Scientific Instruments |volume=44 |issue=12 |pages=1044–1045 |year=1967 |last1=Fasth |first1=J E |last2=Loberg |first2=B |last3=Nordén |first3=H }}</ref>
=== Optical microscopy === In the past, optical microscope has been only used to investigate if the tip is bent microscale imaging at many microscales. This is because the resolution limitation of an optical microscope is about 200 nm. Imaging software including ImageJ allows determination of the curvature, and aspect ratio of the tip. One drawback of this method is that it renders an image of tip which is a object due to the uncertainty in the nanoscale dimension. This problem can be resolved taking images of tip multiple times followed by putting them together into image by confocal microscope with some fluorescent material coating on the tip. Also, it is a time-consuming process considering the necessity of monitoring the wear or damage or degradation of tip by the collision with the surface during scanning the surface after each scan.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1063/1.1144891 |title=Preparation and characterization of tungsten tips for scanning tunneling microscopy |journal=Review of Scientific Instruments |volume=65 |issue=5 |pages=1558–1560 |year=1994 |last1=Cricenti |first1=A |last2=Paparazzo |first2=E |last3=Scarselli |first3=M. A |last4=Moretto |first4=L |last5=Selci |first5=S }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1063/1.98451 |title=''Oxide‐free'' tip for scanning tunneling microscopy |journal=Applied Physics Letters |volume=51 |issue=5 |pages=305–307 |year=1987 |last1=Colton |first1=R. J |last2=Baker |first2=S. M |last3=Baldeschwieler |first3=J. D |last4=Kaiser |first4=W. J |url=https://authors.library.caltech.edu/10187/1/COLapl87.pdf |format=Submitted manuscript }}</ref><ref name="Hacker et al 1992">{{Cite journal |date=1992-07-01 |title=Preparation and characterization of tips for scanning tunneling microscopy of biological specimens |journal=Ultramicroscopy |volume=42-44 |pages=1514–1518 |doi=10.1016/0304-3991(92)90475-Y |last1=Hacker |first1=B |last2=Hillebrand |first2=A |last3=Hartmann |first3=T |last4=Guckenberger |first4=R }}</ref><ref name="SCHWARZ 183–197">{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2818.1994.tb03441.x |title=Tip artefacts in scanning force microscopy |journal=Journal of Microscopy |volume=173 |issue=3 |pages=183–197 |year=1994 |last1=Schwarz |first1=U. D |last2=Haefke |first2=H |last3=Reimann |first3=P |last4=Güntherodt |first4=H.-J }}</ref><ref name="DeRose 203–213">{{Cite journal |last=DeRose |first=J. A. |last2=Revel |first2=J.-P. |date=May 1997 |title=Examination of Atomic (Scanning) Force Microscopy Probe Tips with the Transmission Electron Microscope |url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/microscopy-and-microanalysis/article/examination-of-atomic-scanning-force-microscopy-probe-tips-with-the-transmission-electron-microscope/6294E9E86A1C98300C96CE11C8FBD872 |journal=Microscopy and Microanalysis |volume=3 |issue=3 |pages=203–213 |doi=10.1017/S143192769797015X |issn=1435-8115 |doi-broken-date=2018-08-09 }}</ref>
=== Scanning tunneling spectroscopy === The scanning tunneling spectroscopy (STS) is spectroscopic form of STM in which spectroscopic data based on curve is obtained to analyze the existence of any oxides or impurities on the tip by monitoring the linearity of the curve which represents metallic tunnel junction.<ref name=Feenstra1994>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0039-6028(94)90710-2 |title=Scanning tunneling spectroscopy |journal=Surface Science |volume=299-300 |pages=965–979 |year=1994 |last1=Feenstra |first1=Randall M }}</ref> Generally, cure is non-linear and hence, the tip has a gap like shape around zero bias voltage for oxidized or impure tip whereas the opposite is observed for sharp pure un-oxidized tip.<ref name="Feenstra et al 1987">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0039-6028(87)90170-1 |title=Tunneling spectroscopy of the Si(111)2 × 1 surface |journal=Surface Science |volume=181 |pages=295–306 |year=1987 |last1=Feenstra |first1=R.M |last2=Stroscio |first2=Joseph A |last3=Fein |first3=A.P }}</ref>
=== Auger electron spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy === In Auger electron spectroscopy (AES), any oxides present on the tip surface is sputtered out during in-depth analysis with argon ion beam generated by differentially pumped ion pump followed by comparing the sputtering rate of the oxide with experimental sputtering yields.<ref name=Chang1971>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0039-6028(71)90210-X |title=Auger electron spectroscopy |journal=Surface Science |volume=25 |pages=53–79 |year=1971 |last1=Chang |first1=Chuan C }}</ref> These Auger measurements may estimate the nature of oxides because of the surface contamination and/or composition can be revealed and in some cases thickness of the oxide layer down to 1-3 nm can be estimated. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy also performs similar characterization for the chemical and surface composition by providing information on the binding energy of the surface elements.<ref name=Feenstra1994/><ref name=Chang1971/>
Overall, the aforementioned characterization methods of tips can be categorized in three major classes.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Dongmo |first=Samuel |last2=Villarrubia |first2=John S. |last3=Jones |first3=Samuel N. |last4=Renegar |first4=Thomas B. |last5=Postek |first5=Michael T. |last6=Song |first6=Jun-Feng |date=1998-03-01 |title=Tip Characterization for Scanned Probe Microscope Width Metrology |url=https://www.nist.gov/publications/tip-characterization-scanned-probe-microscope-width-metrology |journal=NIST }}</ref> They are:
* Imaging tip using microscopy- is used to take image of tip with microscopy except scanning probe microscopy (SPM) e.g. scanning tunneling microscopy (STM), atomic force microscopy (AFM) are reported in the references.<ref name="Hacker et al 1992"/><ref name="SCHWARZ 183–197"/><ref name="DeRose 203–213"/> * Using known tip characterizer- shape of tip is deduced by taking image of a sample of known measurement which is known as tip characterizer.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Hierlemann |first=Andreas |last2=K. Campbell |first2=J |last3=Baker |first3=Lane |last4=M. Crooks |first4=R |last5=Ricco |first5=Antonio |date=1998-06-01 |title=Structural Distortion of Dendrimers on Gold Surfaces: A Tapping-Mode AFM Investigation |journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society |volume=120 |issue=21 |pages=5323–5324 |doi=10.1021/ja974283f}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=VAN CLEEF |first=M. |last2=HOLT |first2=S. A. |last3=WATSON |first3=G. S. |last4=MYHRA |first4=S. |date=January 1996 |title=Polystyrene spheres on mica substrates: AFM calibration, tip parameters and scan artefacts |journal=Journal of Microscopy |volume=181 |issue=1 |pages=2–9 |doi=10.1046/j.1365-2818.1996.74351.x }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0039-6028(01)01313-9 |title=A method to improve the quantitative analysis of SFM images at the nanoscale |journal=Surface Science |volume=491 |issue=3 |pages=473–483 |year=2001 |last1=Todd |first1=Brian A |last2=Eppell |first2=Steven J }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|doi=10.1117/12.350822 |chapter=Dimensional metrology with the NIST calibrated atomic force microscope |title=Metrology, Inspection, and Process Control for Microlithography XIII |volume=3677 |pages=20 |series=Metrology, Inspection, and Process Control for Microlithography XIII |year=1999 |last1=Dixson |first1=Ronald G |last2=Koening |first2=Rainer G |last3=Tsai |first3=Vincent W |last4=Fu |first4=Joseph |last5=Vorburger |first5=Theodore V }}</ref> * Blind method- tip characterizer of either known or unknown measurement is used.<ref name="Dongmo 1552">{{Cite journal |last=Dongmo |first=Samuel |date=1996-03-01 |title=Blind restoration method of scanning tunneling and atomic force microscopy images |bibcode=1996JVSTB..14.1552D |journal=Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology B: Microelectronics and Nanometer Structures |volume=14 |issue=2 |page=1552 |doi=10.1116/1.589137 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1116/1.589130 |title=Scanned probe microscope tip characterization without calibrated tip characterizers |journal=Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology B: Microelectronics and Nanometer Structures |volume=14 |issue=2 |pages=1518 |year=1996 |last1=Villarrubia |first1=J. S }}</ref><ref name="Dongmo 1552"/><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1116/1.589138 |title=Blind reconstruction of scanning probe image data |journal=Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology B: Microelectronics and Nanometer Structures |volume=14 |issue=2 |pages=1557 |year=1996 |last1=Williams |first1=P. M }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Villarrubia |first=J. S. |date=July 1997 |title=Algorithms for Scanned Probe Microscope Image Simulation, Surface Reconstruction, and Tip Estimation |journal=Journal of Research of the National Institute of Standards and Technology |volume=102 |issue=4 |pages=425–454 |doi=10.6028/jres.102.030 |pmc=4882144 |pmid=27805154}}</ref>
== Applications == Probes tips have a wide variety of applications in different fields of science and technology. One of the major areas where probe tips are used is for application in SPM i.e., STM<ref name="Tersoff & Hamann 1983"/> and AFM.<ref name=pmid10649994>{{cite journal |last=Yu |first=Min-Feng |last2=Lourie |first2=Oleg |last3=Dyer |first3=Mark J. |last4=Moloni |first4=Katerina |last5=Kelly |first5=Thomas F. |last6=Ruoff |first6=Rodney S. |date=2000-01-28 |title=Strength and Breaking Mechanism of Multiwalled Carbon Nanotubes Under Tensile Load |journal=Science |volume=287 |issue=5453 |pages=637–640 |doi=10.1126/science.287.5453.637 |pmid=10649994 }}</ref> For example, carbon nanotube tips in conjunction with AFM provides an excellent tool for surface characterization in the nanometer realm. CNT tips are also used in tapping-mode Scanning Force Microscopy (SFM), which is a technique where a tip taps a surface by a cantilever driven near resonant frequency of the cantilever. The CNT probe tips fabricated using CVD technique can be used for imaging of biological macromolecules,<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Hafner |first=Jason H. |last2=Cheung |first2=Chin Li |last3=Lieber |first3=Charles M. |date=April 1999 |title=Growth of nanotubes for probe microscopy tips |journal=Nature |volume=398 |issue=6730 |pages=761–762 |doi=10.1038/19658 |url=https://dash.harvard.edu/bitstream/handle/1/2710478/chemistrycheung-17.pdf?sequence=1 |format=Full text }}</ref> semiconductor<ref name="Nguyen et al 2001"/> and chemical structure.<ref name=pmid19713523/> For example, it is possible to obtain intermittent AFM contact image of IgM macromolecules with excellent resolution using single CNT tip. Individual CNT tips can be used for high resolution imaging of protein molecules.
In another work, multiwall carbon nanotube (MWCNT) and Single wall carbon nanotube (SWCNT) tips were used to image amyloid β (1-40) derived protofibrils and fibrils by tapping mode AFM.<ref name=":35" /> Functionalized probes can be used in Chemical Force Microscopy (CFM) to measure intermolecular forces and map chemical functionality.<ref name="Wong et al 1998">{{cite journal |last=Wong |first=Stanislaus S. |last2=Woolley |first2=Adam T. |last3=Joselevich |first3=Ernesto |last4=Cheung |first4=Chin Li |last5=Lieber |first5=Charles M. |date=August 1998 |title=Covalently-Functionalized Single-Walled Carbon Nanotube Probe Tips for Chemical Force Microscopy |journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society |volume=120 |issue=33 |pages=8557–8 |doi=10.1021/ja9817803 }}</ref> Functionalized SWCNT probes can be used for chemically sensitive imaging with high lateral resolution and to study binding energy in chemical and biological system.<ref name="Wong et al 1998"/> Probe tips that have been functionalized with either hydrophobic or hydrophilic molecules can be used to measure the adhesive interaction between hydrophobic-hydrophobic,<ref name=pmid12801659>{{Cite journal |last=Wang |first=Zhigang |last2=Zhou |first2=Chunqing |last3=Wang |first3=Chen |last4=Wan |first4=Lijun |last5=Fang |first5=Xiaohong |last6=Bai |first6=Chunli |date=October 2003 |title=AFM and STM study of beta-amyloid aggregation on graphite |journal=Ultramicroscopy |volume=97 |issue=1–4 |pages=73–79 |doi=10.1016/S0304-3991(03)00031-7 |pmid=12801659 }}</ref> hydrophobic-hydrophilic,<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Wilson |first=Neil R. |last2=Macpherson |first2=Julie V. |date=2009-07-13 |title=Carbon nanotube tips for atomic force microscopy |journal=Nature Nanotechnology |volume=4 |issue=8 |pages=483–491 |doi=10.1038/nnano.2009.154 }}</ref> and hydrophilic-hydrophilic<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Patel |first=N. |last2=Davies |first2=M. C. |last3=Heaton |first3=R. J. |last4=Roberts |first4=C. J. |last5=Tendler |first5=S. J. B. |last6=Williams |first6=P. M. |date=1998-03-01 |title=A scanning probe microscopy study of the physisorption and chemisorption of protein molecules onto carboxylate terminated self-assembled monolayers |journal=Applied Physics A |volume=66 |issue=1 |pages=S569–S574 |doi=10.1007/s003390051203 }}</ref> molecules. From these adhesive interactions the friction image of patterned sample surface can be found.<ref name=pmid17811409/> Probe tips used in force microscopy can provide imaging of structure and dynamics of adsorbate at the nanometer scale.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Noy |first=Aleksandr |last2=Frisbie |first2=C. Daniel |last3=Rozsnyai |first3=Lawrence F. |last4=Wrighton |first4=Mark S. |last5=Lieber |first5=Charles M. |date=August 1995 |title=Chemical Force Microscopy: Exploiting Chemically-Modified Tips To Quantify Adhesion, Friction, and Functional Group Distributions in Molecular Assemblies |journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society |volume=117 |issue=30 |pages=7943–7951 |doi=10.1021/ja00135a012 }}</ref> Self-Assembled Functionalized Organic Thiols onto the surface of Au coated Si<sub>3</sub>N<sub>4</sub> probe tips has been used to study the interaction between molecular groups.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Frisbie |first=C. D. |last2=Rozsnyai |first2=L. F. |last3=Noy |first3=A. |last4=Wrighton |first4=M. S. |last5=Lieber |first5=C. M. |date=1994-09-30 |title=Functional group imaging by chemical force microscopy |journal=Science |volume=265 |issue=5181 |pages=2071–2074 |doi=10.1126/science.265.5181.2071 |pmid=17811409 }}</ref> Again, carbon nanotube probe tips in conjunction with AFM can be used for probing crevices that occur in microelectronic circuits with improved lateral resolution.<ref name="Dai et al 1996"/> Functionality modified probe tips has been to measure the binding force between single protein-ligand pairs.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Lieber |first=Charles M. |last2=Wong |first2=Stanislaus S. |last3=Joselevich |first3=Ernesto |last4=Woolley |first4=Adam T. |last5=Cheung |first5=Chin Li |date=1998-07-02 |title=Covalently functionalized nanotubes as nanometre- sized probes in chemistry and biology |journal=Nature |volume=394 |issue=6688 |pages=52–55 |doi=10.1038/27873 |url=https://dash.harvard.edu/bitstream/handle/1/2710385/chemistrycheung-16.pdf?sequence=1 |format=Full text }}</ref> Probe tips has been in used in tapping mode technique to provide information about the elastic properties of materials.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Howard |first=A. J. |last2=Rye |first2=R. R. |last3=Houston |first3=J. E. |date=1996-02-15 |title=Nanomechanical basis for imaging soft materials with tapping mode atomic force microscopy |bibcode=1996JAP....79.1885H |journal=Journal of Applied Physics |volume=79 |issue=4 |pages=1885–1890 |doi=10.1063/1.361090 }}</ref> Probe tips are also used in mass spectrometer. Enzymatically active probe tips have been used for the enzymatic degradation of analyte. They have also been used as devices to introduce sample into the mass spectrophotometer. For example, trypsin-activated gold (Au/trypsin) probe tips can be used for the peptide mapping of the hen egg lysozyme.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Dogruel |first=David. |last2=Williams |first2=Peter. |last3=Nelson |first3=Randall W. |date=December 1995 |title=Rapid Tryptic Mapping Using Enzymically Active Mass Spectrometer Probe Tips |journal=Analytical Chemistry |volume=67 |issue=23 |pages=4343–4348 |doi=10.1021/ac00119a022 }}</ref>
Atomically sharp probe tips can be used for imaging a single atom in molecule.<ref name=pmid19713523/> An example of visualizing single atoms in water cluster can be seen in Fig. 10.<ref name="Shiotari & Sugimoto">{{Cite journal |last=Shiotari |first=Akitoshi |last2=Sugimoto |first2=Yoshiaki |date=2017-02-03 |title=Ultrahigh-resolution imaging of water networks by atomic force microscopy |journal=Nature Communications |volume=8 |page=14313 |doi=10.1038/ncomms14313 }}</ref> By visualizing single atoms in molecules present on a surface, the scientists can determine bond length, bond order and discrepancies,<ref name=pmid22984067/><ref name=":37" /> if any, in conjugation which was supposed to be impossible by experimental work. Fig. 9 shows experimentally determined bond order in poly aromatic compound which was thought to be very hard in past.<ref name="Wang et al 2017">{{cite journal |doi=10.1038/s41467-017-01934-1 |title=Exploration of pyrazine-embedded antiaromatic polycyclic hydrocarbons generated by solution and on-surface azomethine ylide homocoupling |journal=Nature Communications |volume=8 |year=2017 |last1=Wang |first1=Xiao-Ye |last2=Richter |first2=Marcus |last3=He |first3=Yuanqin |last4=Björk |first4=Jonas |last5=Riss |first5=Alexander |last6=Rajesh |first6=Raju |last7=Garnica |first7=Manuela |last8=Hennersdorf |first8=Felix |last9=Weigand |first9=Jan J |last10=Narita |first10=Akimitsu |last11=Berger |first11=Reinhard |last12=Feng |first12=Xinliang |last13=Auwärter |first13=Willi |last14=Barth |first14=Johannes V |last15=Palma |first15=Carlos-Andres |last16=Müllen |first16=Klaus }}</ref>
[[File:Bond order of aromatic.png|thumb|Fig. 9: On-surface homocoupling of precursor '''5c''' yields fully planar and neutral diaza-HBC '''7c''' on Ag(111). '''a''' Scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) overview of reaction product and unreacted species on Ag(111). ''V'' <sub>s</sub> = 30 mV, ''I'' <sub>t</sub> = 10 pA. '''b''' Constant-height STM data of diaza-HBC with partially superposed molecular model. ''V'' <sub>s</sub> = 5 mV. '''c''' Frequency-modulated atomic force microscopy (FM-AFM) and '''d''' Laplace-filtered FM-AFM data reveal details in the molecular structure. Apparent C = C distance 1.0 Å (black), and N–C 1.8 Å (blue). '''e''' FM-AFM simulations of '''7c''' employing '''a''' neutral tip. Apparent C = C distance 1.5 Å (black), N–C 1.5 Å (blue). '''f''' FM-AFM simulations employing a negatively charged probe tip. Apparent C = C distance 1.3 Å (black), N-C 1.9 Å (blue). For simulation parameters see Methods. '''g'''–'''n''' Constant-height STM data ('''g''', '''i''', '''k''', '''m''') at different biases and corresponding ('''h''', '''j''', '''l''', '''n''') DFT simulations. White arrows point to N atoms oriented along the diaza-HBC symmetry axis. Scale bars ('''a''') 20 Å, ('''b'''–'''f''') 2 Å, ('''g'''–'''n''') 5 Å<ref name="Wang et al 2017"/>]]
[[File:Water Single Atom.png|thumb|Fig. 10: (a) Schematic of STM/AFM measurement for pentagonal water chains on Cu(110) with a CO-terminal tip. Red, black, white and brown spheres show O, C, H and Cu atoms, respectively. ('''b''') Side-view schematic of the water chain. Red (yellow) spheres represent O atoms of horizontal (vertical) H<sub>2</sub>O. ('''c''') STM image of the water chains on Cu(110) with a CO-terminal tip (sample bias ''V''=30 mV, tunneling current ''I''=20 pA). The zigzag chains have terminals (red ellipses). ('''d''','''e''') STM (''V''=30 mV, ''I''=20 pA) and AFM (''V''=0 mV, oscillation amplitude ''A''=2 Å) images, respectively, of a water chain including a kink and a terminal. An atomic structure of the chain is superposed in '''d'''. The tip height in '''e''' was set over the bare surface under the same conditions as in '''d'''. ('''f''') Δ''f'' map of the pentagonal chain at a tip height Δ''z''=−2 Å (''A''=1 Å). ('''g''') Δ''f''(''Δz'') curves recorded over the markers in '''f'''. ('''h''') Force map of the chain at Δ''z''=−1.95 Å after subtraction of the force for the bare surface ''F''<sub>Cu</sub>. ('''i''') Force curves over the makers in '''f''' after subtraction of ''F''<sub>Cu</sub>(Δ''z''). Scale bars, 50 Å ('''c'''); 10 Å ('''d''','''e'''); 3 Å ('''f''','''h''').<ref name="Shiotari & Sugimoto"/>]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{refimprove|date=December 2009}} {{Wiktionary}} [[File:Origin histograma raw data.png|thumb|right|200px|The two columns to the right of the left-most column in this computerized table are raw data.]] '''Raw data''', also known as '''primary data''', is [[data]] (e.g., numbers, instrument readings, figures, etc.) collected from a source. If a scientist sets up a computerized [[thermometer]] which records the temperature of a chemical mixture in a test tube every minute, the list of temperature readings for every minute, as printed out on a spreadsheet or viewed on a computer screen is "raw data". Raw data has not been subjected to processing, "cleaning" by researchers to remove [[outlier]]s, obvious instrument reading errors or data entry errors, or any analysis (e.g., determining [[central tendency]] aspects such as the [[arithmetic mean|average]] or [[median]] result). As well, raw data has not been subject to any other manipulation by a software program or a human researcher, analyst or technician. It is also referred to as ''primary'' data. Raw data is a relative term (see [[data]]), because even once raw data has been "cleaned" and processed by one team of researchers, another team may consider this processed data to be "raw data" for another stage of research. Raw data can be inputted to a [[computer program]] or used in manual procedures such as analyzing [[statistics]] from a [[statistical survey|survey]]. The term "raw data" can refer to the [[Binary number|binary]] data on electronic storage devices, such as hard disk drives (also referred to as "low-level data").
== Generating data == Data has two ways of being created or generated. The first is what is called 'captured data',<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=The Data Revolution|last=Kitchin|first=Rob|publisher=Sage|year=2014|isbn=|location=United States|pages=6|via=}}</ref> and is found through purposeful investigation or analysis. The second is called 'exhaust data',<ref name=":0" /> and is gathered usually by machines or terminals as a secondary function. For example, cash registers, smartphones, and speedometers serve a main function but may collect data as a secondary task. Exhaustive data is usually too large or of little use to process and becomes 'transient'<ref name=":0" /> or thrown away.
==Examples== In [[computing]], raw data may have the following attributes: it may possibly contain human, machine, or instrument errors, it may not be validated; it might be in different areen ([[colloquial]]) formats; [[Code|uncoded]] or unformatted; or some entries might be "suspect" (e.g., [[outlier]]s), requiring [[confirmation]] or [[citation]]. For example, a data input sheet might contain dates as raw data in many forms: "31st January 1999", "31/01/1999", "31/1/99", "31 Jan", or "today". Once captured, this raw data may be [[Data processing|processed]] stored as a normalized format, perhaps a [[Julian date]], to make it easier for computers and humans to interpret during later processing. Raw data (sometimes colloquially called "sourcey" data or "eggy" data, the latter a reference to the data being "uncooked", that is, "unprocessed", like a raw [[egg]]) are the data input to processing. A distinction is made between ''data'' and ''information'', to the effect that information is the ''end'' product of ''data'' processing. Raw data that has undergone processing are sometimes referred to as "cooked" data in a colloquial sense.{{dubious|date=September 2016}} Although raw data has the potential to be transformed into "[[information]]," extraction, organization, analysis and formatting for presentation are required before raw data can be transformed into usable information.
For example, a [[point-of-sale terminal]] (POS terminal, a computerized [[cash register]]) in a busy supermarket collects huge volumes of raw data each day about customers' purchases. However, this list of grocery items and their prices and the time and date of purchase does not yield much information until it is processed. Once processed and analyzed by a [[software program]] or even by a researcher using a pen and paper and a [[calculator]], this raw data may indicate the particular items that each customer buys, when they buy them, and at what price; as well, an analyst or manager could calculate the average total sales per customer or the average expenditure per day of the week by hour. This processed and analyzed data provides information for the manager, that the manager could then use to help her determine, for example, how many cashiers to hire and at what times. Such ''information'' could then become ''data'' for further processing, for example as part of a predictive [[marketing]] campaign. As a result of processing, raw data sometimes ends up being put in a [[database]], which enables the raw data to become accessible for further processing and analysis in any number of different ways.
[[Tim Berners-Lee]] (inventor of the [[World Wide Web]]) argues that sharing raw data is important for society. [http://www.w3.org/2009/Talks/0204-ted-tbl/#(34) Inspired] by [http://blog.okfn.org/2007/11/07/give-us-the-data-raw-and-give-it-to-us-now/ a post] by [[Rufus Pollock]] of the [[Open Knowledge Foundation]] his call to action is [http://www.ted.com/index.php/talks/tim_berners_lee_on_the_next_web.html "Raw Data Now"], meaning that everyone should demand that governments and businesses share the data they collect as raw data. He points out that "data drives a huge amount of what happens in our lives… because somebody takes the data and does something with it." To Berners-Lee, it is essentially from this sharing of raw data, that advances in science will emerge. Advocates of [[open data]] argue that once citizens and civil society organizations have access to data from businesses and governments, it will enable citizens and NGOs to do their ''own'' analysis of the data, which can empower people and civil society. For example, a government may claim that its policies are reducing the [[unemployment rate]], but a [[poverty]] advocacy group may be able to have its staff [[econometrics|econometricians]] do their own analysis of the raw data, which may lead this group to draw different conclusions about the data set.
== Further reading ==
* [http://blog.okfn.org/2007/11/07/give-us-the-data-raw-and-give-it-to-us-now/ Give Us the Data Raw, and Give it to Us Now] - the blog post from Rufus Pollock that [http://www.w3.org/2009/Talks/0204-ted-tbl/#(34) inspired] Tim Berners-Lee * [http://computemagazine.com/man-who-invented-world-wide-web-gives-new-definition/ Tim Berners-Lee Gives the Web a New Definition]

'''Researchsome''' belongs to the -omics set of words, which comprises [[genomics]], [[proteomics]], [[metabolomics]] and related words dealing with scientific research, mostly in the biological sciences and related disciplines, like [[bioinformatics]].
== Origin of term == Devised partly as a joke, the term was coined by Ivan Erill, from [[UMBC]], and first used in an oral communication at the 15th Evolutionary Biology Meeting at Marseilles (France) in 2011.<ref>(2011) [http://sites.univ-provence.fr/evol-cgr/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=40&Itemid=40 "15th EBM PROGRAM"] ''Evolutionary Biology Meeting at Marseilles'.' Retrieved December 14, 2011.</ref> [[Image:Erill 2011 EBM Conference Researchsome.png|thumb|The original researchsome slide by Ivan Erill at the 2011 EBM meeting]] As opposed to other -omic words, which originate as [[portmanteau]] from incorrect application of either the -some suffix (derived from the Greek σῶμα (soma, body) as in [[chromosome]] or the -nome suffix (from the Greek νόμος (nomos, "custom" or "law") as in [[economics]]),<ref name="pmid118166670">{{cite journal | author = Yadav SP | title = The wholeness in suffix -omics, -omes, and the word om | journal = J Biomol Tech | volume = 18 | issue = 5 | pages = 277 | year = 2007 | pmid = 18166670 | doi = | url = | issn = | pmc=2392988}}</ref><ref name="pmid9450566">{{cite journal | author = Kuska B | title = Beer, Bethesda, and biology: how "genomics" came into being | journal = J Natl Cancer Inst | volume = 90 | issue = 2 | pages = 93 | year = 1998 | pmid = 9450566 | doi = 10.1093/jnci/90.2.93| url = | issn = }}</ref><ref>Jong Bhak (2011) [http://omics.org/index.php/History_of_Omics "History of Omics"] ''The History of Omics: as a generic name for various omics and a standalone biology discipline.' Retrieved December 14, 2011.</ref> researchsome is among the few newly minted words in the biosciences that derives properly from soma and should be read as "body of research". Obviously, the word has a [[double entendre]] interpretation as "some research".
== Application == As an entity, the researchsome is meant to be a graphical representation of the body of research conducted by a particular individual or organization. It depicts research fields and their interconnections, much in the same way that graphical renditions of [[interactome]]s outline molecules and their interactions. In its original application, the researchsome was designed to convey a rapid overview of a researcher's areas of expertise onto which the relevant fields for a given lecture or talk could be highlighted.
==See also== * [[List of omics topics in biology]] * [[Omics]] * [[Genome]] * [[Chromosome]]

In [[science]], '''priority''' is the credit given to the individual or group of individuals who first made the discovery or propose the theory. Fame and honours usually go to the first person or group to publish a new finding, even if several researchers arrived at the same conclusion independently and at the same time. Thus between two or more independent discoverers, the first to make formal publication is the legitimate winner. Hence, the tradition is often referred to as the '''priority rule''', the procedure of which is nicely summed up in a phrase "[[publish or perish]]", because there are no second prizes.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Strevens M|year=2003 |title= The Role of the Priority Rule in Science| journal=The Journal of Philosophy |volume=100 |issue=3 |pages=55–79| pmid= |pmc= |jstor=3655792}}</ref> In a way, the race to be first inspires risk-taking that can lead to scientific breakthroughs which is beneficial to the society (such as discovery of [[malaria|malaria transmission]], [[DNA]], [[HIV]], etc.); on the other hand, it can create an unhealthy competition, thus, becoming detrimental to scientific progress.<ref name=fang>{{cite journal|vauthors=Fang FC, Casadevall A|year=2012 |title= Reforming science: structural reforms | journal=Infect Immun|volume=80 |issue=3 |pages=897–901 |pmid= 22184420| pmc=3294664|doi= 10.1128/IAI.06184-11}}</ref>
==Priority disputes== Priority becomes a difficult issue usually in the context of priority disputes, where the priority for a given theory, understanding, or discovery comes into question. In most cases historians of science disdain retrospective priority disputes as enterprises which generally lack understanding about the nature of scientific change and usually involve gross misreadings of the past to support the idea of a long-lost priority claim. Historian and biologist [[Stephen Jay Gould]] once remarked that "debates about the priority of ideas are usually among the most misdirected in the history of science."<ref>Gould SJ (1977). ''Ontogeny and Phylogeny''. Cambridge, Mass: Harvard University Press, p. 35.</ref>
[[Richard Feynman]] told [[Freeman Dyson]] that he avoided priority disputes by "Always giv[ing] the bastards more credit than they deserve." Dyson remarked that he also follows this rule, and that this practice is "remarkably effective for avoiding quarrels and making friends." <ref>Freeman Dyson, 2011, "The Dramatic Picture of Richard Feynman, " New York Review of Books, July 14, 2011. Reprinted in {{ISBN|9781590178546}}</ref>
==Origin==
The priority rule came into existence before or as soon as modern scientific methods were established. For example, the earliest documented controversy was a bitter claim between [[Isaac Newton]] and [[Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz]] in the 17th century about priority in the invention of [[calculus]]. This particular incidence clearly shows human biases and prejudice. It has become unanimously accepted that both the mathematicians independently developed calculus. Since then priority has caused a number of historical maladies in the history of science.<ref name=fang/><ref>{{cite web| vauthors= Fang FC, Casadevall A|title=Intense Competition among Scientists Has Gotten out of Hand|date=25 July 2012| url= http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=intense-competition-among-scientists-gotten-out-of-hand |work= Scientific American |publisher= Scientific American, a Division of Nature America, Inc.|accessdate= 2013-05-31}}</ref> In the cases of scientists who have since achieved incredible levels of popularity, such as [[Charles Darwin]] and [[Albert Einstein]], priority questions are often rooted in taking too seriously the myth of the "[[Heroic theory of invention and scientific development|lone genius]]" which is often cultivated around such quasi-mythic figures (see [[Great Man theory]] and [[Whig history]]). In an attempt to laud such scientists as visionaries, the context in which they worked is often neglected by popularizers, making it appear as if they worked without assistance or without reference to other work, something which is rarely the case.
==See also== * [[List of scientific priority disputes]] * [[Multiple discovery]] * [[Stigler's law]] * [[Priority certificate]] * [[Priority right]] in patent law
